title: Ireland gains independence from Britain
description: The Catholic church control the vast majority of schools and hospitals.

title: Censorship of Publications Board formed
description: Responsible for censoring printed media, the intitial government-appointed committee contained a Catholic priest.

title: Irish citizen, Jimmy Gralton is deported to the US
description: Jimmy had served in the US navy and obtained US citizenship as result. On his return to Ireland he set up a local dance hall, and this combined with the fact that he was socialist drew the ire of the Catholic church among others. He was deported on the grounds that as an American citizen, he was ‘an undesirable alien’.

title: A priest leads thousands of people in an anti-jazz march
description: This was the beginning of a campaign that called on the government to close the dance halls and ban all foreign dances in Ireland.

title: The sale of contraception is banned
description: It also became an offence to publish material advocating contraception and birth control.

title: Edna O'Brien's 'The Country Girls' is banned
description: Banned for sexually explicit content and burned by the church.

title: Catholics allowed to attend Trinity College Dublin
description: Originally a Protestant university but even when the university themselves opened their doors to Catholics the Catholic church prevented it. Apparently they were concerned that Catholic students would be corrupted fraternising with Protestants. So prior to 1970 Catholic students had to get special dispensation from the church to attend the univeristy.

title: A group of activists travel to Belfast to buy contraceptives
description: In an act known as the Contraceptive Train the group travlled over the border to buy and bring back contraceptives that were illegal in Ireland.

title: Ireland joins the EEC (now the EU)
The marriage bar comes to an end
description: The marriage bar dictated that women working in the civil service had to give up their jobs upon getting married.

title: Pope John Paul II visits Ireland
description: 1.25 million, a third of the population, attended the mass he said in Dublin.

title: Monty Python's The Life of Brian' is banned
description: Banned until 1987 for its religious satire.

title: Contraceptives are finally available on prescription
description: The change in the law allowed access to contraceptives for family planning, so they were still difficult to get if you were unmarried.

title: Gay man Declan Flynn murdered in Dublin
description: Attacked in a public park by 5 teenagers. All 5 walked free with suspended sentences. The judge said there was 'no element of correction required' as they had 'come from good homes'.

title: The first gay pride parade takes place in Dublin
The 8th amendment is introduced
description: This amendment to the constitution gave equal right to life to the pregnant woman and the unborn. Abortion was already illegal in Ireland but the result of this ammendment in the ensuing decades was that women were denied helathcare and in some cases lost their lives. 67% voted in favour of the amendment.

title: 15 year-old Ann Lovett dies after giving birth at a religious grotto on the side of the road
Condoms are finally available without prescription.
description: But their sale is still restrcited to pharmacies and family planning centres.

title: Irish Family Planning Association are convicted for selling condoms in Virgin Megastore
description: Richard Branson testifies in court in Dublin on their behalf. They are fined £500, which U2 pays.

title: Mary Robinson becomes the first female president of Ireland
description: In 1997 she left the position to become UN High Commissioner for Human Rights.

title: The X case establishs the right of Irish women to an abortion if the women is at risk of committing suicide.
description: The case involved a 14 year old girl who was preganant as the result of rape. She intented to travel to London with her parents to get an abortion. The parents asked the police if DNA evidence from the foetus would be admissable in court for the rape trial. Police sought the advice of the attorney general, who then sought an injuction preventing her from travelling for the abortion. The family appealed this in the Irish supreme court.

title: Bishop Eamon Casey forced to resign after it was revealed that he had fathered a child
description: He had an affair with American Annie Murphy. He urged her to give up the child for adoption but she refused. He made fraudulent covert payments for the childs welfare using diocesan funds. Years later it was revealed that there were multiple sex abuse claims against him which the church had covered up.

title: Sinéad O'Connor rips up a picture of the pope on Saturday Night Live in the US
description: She said the words 'Fight the real enemy' as she tore the picture. Sinéad had spent 18 months at a Magdelene Laundry as a teenager. Magdalene laundires were Catholic-run instituions where women were imprisoned, forced to carry out unpaid labour and subjected to severe psychological and physical maltreatment. So called because they ran for-profit businesses, primarily laundries.

title: A referendum passes guaranteeing the right to travel abroad for an abortion
description: An estimated 10 women a day were travelling to the UK for abortions.

title: Homosexuality is decriminalised
Condoms are deregulated
description: They can now be bought at ordinary retail locations such as shops, pubs etc.

title: Remains of 155 women are found on the site of a former Magdalene Laundry
Divorce becomes legal
description: The referendum on divorce in 1995 passed by the narrow majority of 50.3%. In a previous referendum on the topic in 1986 the no vote won by a margin of 25%.

title: The Ferns report is released
description: The report identified more than 100 allegations of child sex abuse in the south-east of Ireland and outlined the failure of the church to take any action.

title: The Ryan Report is published
description: It was an expansive inquiry into child abuse at residential institutions for children run by the Catholic Church between 1936 and 1999.

title: Savita Halappanavar dies after being denied an abortion
description: Savita experienced preganancy complications, but was denied an abortion as there was a foetal heatbeat. She went into septic shock. Both her and the foetus died. Her death was a catalyst for the pro-choice movement.

title: 800 babies found buried in a septic tank on the grounds of a former mother and baby home
description: Discovery made by amateur historian, Catherine Corless, on what was once the grounds of a home for unwed mothers run by a Catholic order. Research would later show that on average, a child from the home died every two weeks between 1925 and 1961.

title: Ireland becomes the first country to legalise gay marriage by popular vote
description: Passing by a sizeable majority of 62%.

title: The 8th amendment is repealed
description: 66.4% voted in favour of repealing the amendment. Women will now be able to get abortions in Ireland up to 12 weeks.

title: The release of the Mother and Baby homes report
description: The report detailed that around 9,000 children, one in seven of those born in the 18 institutions covered in the report had died in them between 1922 and 1998, double the rate of infant mortality in the general population.

title: Government signs off on a new state maternity hospital to be built on the grounds of a Catholic order.
description: The sign off had been delayed by controversy and protests as the public questioned whether the religious order would allow for a full range of services including terminations and IVF. This remains to be seen as the hospital has not been built yet.

title: The free contraception scheme is introduced
description: Prescription contraception is now free for 17-25 year olds. The scheme is later expanded to 16-35 year olds.

title: The government launches a redress scheme for surviviors of mother and baby homes
description: As it stands the scheme is estimated to cost €1.5 billion and the majority of the cost will likely be borne by the taxpayer as religious institutions have only contributed about 16%.
